channel.description: Recent content in Delivery on Hareesh Kanchanepally

item.title: On Holding things lightly - Weeknotes: 16 - 22 Sep
item.description: I am reminded of a story I read as a child as I reflect on this last week. Kids were getting terrified of a snake in a field when they want to play there. One day, a sage passed through the field, observes this, and suggests the snake to ease off, and let it share the field with all others. Snake listens, and stops resorting to aggression. Over the next few months, the kids, the passer-bys and others get accustomed to the now insipid snake. Some kids even start using it as a toy, thrashing across the field and so on. Sage – on his return from his travels –passes through the field again and realises the sorry state of the snake. It tells the snake that his advice to her was not to be aggressive and selfish, but he never meant her to become the opposite and become submissive, retired, insipid.

item.title: Week 31 #Weeknotes: Aug 5-9, 2024
item.description:
Work front #

During my last published #weeknotes, I mentioned about doing a 360-degree risk review of my portfolio of programmes and coming up with a list ahead of a leadership offsite. I feel I ought to share that here.

  • Confusion amongst cross-functional delivery vs domain-based organisation structure.

  • Confusion between iterative model of delivery vs stage-gates way of monitoring/governance

  • Lack of end-to-end focus on product delivery from all the disciplines involves.

item.title: Week 20, May 13-19, 2024
item.description:
Another whirl-wind of a week with lots packed in. Let’s jump right-in.

Work #

Generalizations are super easy, and we like to theorize and come up with very assured plans or “solutions” to some of our wicked problems. I am going to generalize a bit now, but by saying how easy it is to do, I ask you to consider this theory with a disclaimer, a caution, and as my opinion, inviting you to share yours. So, here’s my theory about the current problems we face in product development/delivery:

item.title: Conducting Program/Release retrospectives
item.description:
1. What’s the Difference between a release retro, lessons learnt, sprint retro?
  2. Conducting a release retrospective – a “tried and tested” framework
  3. Sample Activities for Each Stage:
  4. Best Practices for Leading and Managing Retrospectives:
  5. What about a repository of the learnings/retrospectives?

Technical programme management and product execution is a practice. We develop our skills by doing the work regularly and repeatedly: one project, one feature, one service at a time. All of us know that to improve, we need to learn from our previous experience and build on from there. Each framework, method, playbook in execution has in its core ways a principle to inspect and adapt.  Here’s a framework that I refined over time to conduct these release retrospectives effectively. Original inspiration comes from: Agile Retrospectives by Esther D and Diana L.

item.title: Navigating the Spectrum of Collaboration in Product Development (Building on John Cutler's Insights)
item.description: John Cutler’s insightful ideas on convergence modes (Part 1, Part 2, and Part 3) in product development especially in handling dependencies effectively, offered a helpful perspective for understanding how collaboration styles affect project outcomes. John proposes four different modes/ways of working: Fully Embedded, Collaborative, Supportive, Transactional. And suggests that, to “make dependency management easier, you should ask yourself: “What type of working model SHOULD we use for this work?”. This struck a chord with me. In the past few years, especially in 2023, I personally experimented with two modes for two different projects: one project that integrated different skillsets into a single, unified, cross-functional, and fully embedded team, and the other that relied on transactional ways of working supported by a framework of project management processes. Based on this personal experience, I asked myself a question: if you decide on a particular mode of convergence at the outset of a project, do the different phases require a dynamic shift between full immersion and focused transactional interactions?

item.title: The Art of Launching a Tech Program: My 15-Year Playbook
item.description: Fifteen years ago, a simple question from my boss ignited a flame that still burns bright: “Can you make this idea fly?” That “idea” became my first foray into the exhilarating world of technical program management (TPM), a journey that has since woven its way through over 40 tech projects and a dozen intricate, multi-team programs. From nimble startups to sprawling enterprises, I’ve learned that while contexts may differ, the bedrock of success lies in a meticulous “set-up” phase. This isn’t a rigid checklist, but rather a playbook honed through experience, designed to de-risk delivery and unlock early learning. So, gather around, fellow journeymen, and let’s delve into the secrets that unlock high-flying tech programs.

item.title: Employing System Thinking to Technical Programme Management
item.description: Embarking on the integration of WeChat Pay for our Chinese customers was not just a project; it was a riveting exploration of dependencies, interconnections, and the intricate dance of technology in a dynamic ecosystem. This journey demanded more than conventional project management—it required a masterclass in systems thinking. In this playbook, we unravel the saga and distil the lessons learned into actionable insights for fellow technology program managers.

item.title: S01E03: #weeknotes: 16-20 January
item.description:
A Smooth Transition into 2023: Quarterly Planning, Insights, and Dune

The year 2022 concluded with the same energy and flavor as its preceding months, but 2023 carries an undercurrent of solidity and assurance. As we navigate the early weeks of this new year, several key themes have emerged, shaping my focus and approach.

Quarterly Planning: Inceptions and Construction Beginnings

The beginning is always delicate. As we embark on this quarter’s planning, Dune’s profound quote resonates deeply: “Beginnings are delicate. They must be nurtured like small flames.” We must carefully consider our goals, strategies, and resource allocation, ensuring that every initiative ignites with the potential to flourish.

item.title: S01E02: #weeknotes: 9-13 January
item.description:
Though the year 23 started off with same fervour and flavour experience end of 22, there’s some solidity and assuredness to this year. There were numerous posts on the Weeks

Key themes of focus this week (9 -13 Jan, 23) #

  • Performance review: What’s the year 22 was like and what I can take from it into 23.

  • Quarterly planning.

  • Feature vs Component teams.

  • New Portfolio ownership.

Key insights, feelings, and actions from this week (09 - 13 Jan, 23) #

  • Probably, Just, Maybe, and Perhaps. - Conversation with Chris/Richard re. MSC/Phase 4 combination.

item.title: Notes from the week: 2-6 January
item.description: Philippa Perry wrote a very useful book, “How to Stay Sane”, which I am reading currently, and the first step that Philippa recommends is to allocate time for self-reflection (along with a prescribed format to do that reflection - the remainder of the post is loosely based on that prescription). Now, however, we all know that self-reflection is something we “need to” do, “love to” do, but at least in my case, never do it enough and/or consistently. Coincidentally, I have been a fan of the weeknotes that Jonny Williams has been publishing throughout the last year and I found them a useful format to not only reflect but to share the notes from the world. There’s intentionality in it and also a social commitment that I love. So, here we go: here’s the first of the 2023! Oh, wishing you a happy new year, by the way (if I can still wish you on the 09th of Jan).
